column1: Phase transition;19;G-META-13-8;MCQS;45;A 0.2 wt.% plain carbon steel sheet is heated and equilibrated in the inter-critical region followed by instant water quenching. column2: the correct answer is:

column1: When a 0.2 wt.% plain carbon steel sheet is heated and equilibrated in the inter-critical region
column2: it means that the steel is heated to a temperature between the upper critical temperature (A3) and the lower critical temperature (A1) of the steel. This region is also known as the ""inter-critical"" or ""two-phase"" region
column3: where both austenite and ferrite phases coexist.

column1: When the steel is then instantaneously water quenched
column2: the austenite phase will transform into martensite
column3: while the ferrite phase will remain unchanged. Therefore
column4: the resulting microstructure will consist of a mixture of proeutectoid ferrite (which was present before quenching) and martensite (which formed during quenching).

column1: Option (A) is incorrect because the steel is not fully austenitized
column2: so it will not transform fully into martensite. Option (C) is also incorrect because pearlite is not expected to form in this scenario. Option (D) is incorrect because austenite is not stable at room temperature
column3: so it will not be present in the microstructure after quenching.";;B;1;

column1: Material processing;11;G-META-14-18;MCQS;30;Which one of the following can avoid weld decay of austenitic stainless steels?  (A) Reducing carbon content (B) Increasing carbon content (C) Eliminating strong carbide formers (D) Decreasing chromium content;"Based on the properties of austenitic stainless steels
column2: the correct answer is:
also known as sensitization
column3: is a phenomenon that occurs in austenitic stainless steels when they are heated to a certain temperature range (typically between 450°C to 850°C) during welding or other thermal processes. This can cause the formation of chromium carbides at the grain boundaries
column4: leading to a depletion of chromium in the surrounding area and reducing the corrosion resistance of the material.

column1: Reducing the carbon content of the steel can help to minimize the formation of chromium carbides and thus avoid weld decay. This is because carbon is a key element in the formation of these carbides
column2: so reducing its presence in the steel reduces the likelihood of sensitization occurring.

column1: Increasing carbon content (option B) would actually increase the likelihood of weld decay
column2: while eliminating strong carbide formers (option C) might help
column3: but reducing carbon content is a more direct and effective way to avoid weld decay. Decreasing chromium content (option D) would also be detrimental to the corrosion resistance of the steel.";;A;1;

column2: let's analyze:

column1: Coble creep is a type of diffusion creep that occurs in polycrystalline materials
column2: where the creep rate is influenced by grain boundary diffusion. In Coble creep
column3: the creep rate increases with decreasing grain size because there are more grain boundaries available for diffusion to occur. This is because grain boundaries have higher diffusivity than the bulk material
column4: so reducing the grain size increases the overall diffusivity of the material
column5: leading to a higher creep rate.

column2: about the reason [R]: Grain boundaries do act as a barrier to dislocation motion
column3: but this is not directly related to Coble creep. In fact
column4: Coble creep is a diffusion-controlled process
column5: whereas dislocation motion is related to plastic deformation.

column2: we have:

column2: but not directly related to Coble creep.

column1: Material manufacturing;89;G-META-22-25;MCQS;36;Which one of the following modern practices is used for retarding the solution loss reaction in blast furnace ironmaking?  (A) High top pressure (B) Bell-less top (C) Pulverized coal injection (D) Rotating chute for burden distribution ;"A blast furnace question!

column2: I can tell you that the correct answer is:

column1: Here's why: High top pressure is a modern practice used to reduce the solution loss reaction in blast furnace ironmaking. The solution loss reaction is an undesirable reaction that occurs between the iron ore and the slag
column2: resulting in a loss of iron units. By increasing the top pressure
column3: the reaction rate is reduced
column4: and the solution loss reaction is minimized.

column1: The other options are not directly related to retarding the solution loss reaction:
* (B) Bell-less top: This is a design modification to improve charging and distribution of materials.
* (C) Pulverized coal injection: This is a method to inject fuel into the furnace
column2: which can improve efficiency but doesn't directly affect the solution loss reaction.

column1: * (D) Rotating chute for burden distribution: This is a mechanism to improve the distribution of materials in the furnace
column2: but it doesn't have a direct impact on the solution loss reaction.
the correct answer is (A) High top pressure.";;A;1;

column5: rigid state to a more flexible

column3: also changes significantly during the glass transition.

column1: * (A) Tg appears above the melting temperature in a perfectly crystalline material
column2: not below.

* (C) Thermal expansion coefficient does change during the glass transition.

column6: leading to a discontinuity in the heat capacity.

column1: Miscellaneous;2;G-XEC-2017-16;MCQS;51;Which of the following statement(s) is/are true: (i) All piezoelectric materials are necessarily ferroelectric (ii) All ferroelectric materials are necessarily piezoelectric (iii) All pyroelectric materials are necessarily piezoelectric (iv) All pyroelectric materials are necessarily ferroelectric  (A) (i) and (ii) (B) (ii) and (iii) (C) (i) and (iv) (D) (ii) and (iv);"A nice question about materials science!

(i) All piezoelectric materials are necessarily ferroelectric: **True**. Piezoelectricity is a property of certain materials that generate an electric charge in response to mechanical stress. Ferroelectricity is a specific type of piezoelectricity that exhibits spontaneous electric polarization. All piezoelectric materials are not necessarily ferroelectric
column2: but all ferroelectric materials are piezoelectric.

column1: (ii) All ferroelectric materials are necessarily piezoelectric: **True**. As mentioned earlier
column2: ferroelectricity is a type of piezoelectricity
column3: so all ferroelectric materials are piezoelectric.

column1: (iii) All pyroelectric materials are necessarily piezoelectric: **True**. Pyroelectricity is the ability of a material to generate an electric charge in response to a change in temperature. All pyroelectric materials are piezoelectric
column2: as they can generate an electric charge in response to a change in temperature
column3: which is a type of mechanical stress.

column1: (iv) All pyroelectric materials are necessarily ferroelectric: **False**. While all pyroelectric materials are piezoelectric
column2: not all pyroelectric materials are ferroelectric. Ferroelectricity requires spontaneous electric polarization
column3: which is not a necessary condition for pyroelectricity.

column1: Atomic structure;36;G-XEC-2017-19;MCQS;86;An inorganic material that is transparent under solar light appears coloured when doped with transition metal ions. The possible reason(s) for the colour is/are: (i) The electronic energy levels of the host materials changes significantly by doping (ii) The doped element selectively absorbs certain wavelength of light other than the perceived colour (iii) The doped element emits radiation of specific wavelength. Which of the previous statement(s) is/are true?  (A) Only (i) (B) Both (i) and (ii) (C) Both (i) and (iii) (D) Both (ii) and (iii);"The correct answer is:
When an inorganic material is doped with transition metal ions
column2: it can exhibit color due to the selective absorption of certain wavelengths of light by the doped element. This is known as the ""d-block"" or ""transition metal"" effect.

column1: Option (ii) is correct because the doped element selectively absorbs certain wavelengths of light
column2: which are not perceived as the color. For example
column3: if the material appears blue
column4: it means that the doped element has absorbed the red and yellow wavelengths of light
column5: leaving only the blue wavelength to be perceived by the human eye.

column1: Option (iii) is also correct because the doped element can emit radiation of specific wavelengths
column2: which can contribute to the observed color. This is known as fluorescence or phosphorescence.

column1: Option (i) is incorrect because the electronic energy levels of the host material do not change significantly by doping. The color is primarily due to the absorption and emission properties of the doped element.

column2: the correct answer is (D) Both (ii) and (iii).";;D;1;

column2: such as hydrogen bonding or van der Waals forces

column1: Material manufacturing;5;G-XEC-2019-12;MCQS;53;Which one of the following conditions will NOT favour the separation of impurities in zone refining process? column2: the correct answer is:

column1: * (B) Increase in the solubility of impurities in solid as compared to that in liquid phase

column2: the impurities are separated based on their differences in solubility between the solid and liquid phases. If the impurities are more soluble in the solid phase than in the liquid phase
column3: it will be more difficult to separate them from the pure material. This is because the impurities will tend to remain in the solid phase
column4: rather than being rejected into the liquid phase.

column1: The other options are not correct because:
* (A) An increase in the gap between the solidus and liquidus lines can actually favor the separation of impurities
column2: as it allows for a greater difference in solubility between the two phases.

column1: * (C) Agitation of the melt can help to promote mixing and increase the efficiency of the zone refining process.
* (D) A low cooling rate of the melt can also favor the separation of impurities
column2: as it allows for a more gradual and controlled solidification process.
the correct answer is (B).";;B;1;

where Na+ ions occupy one type of lattice site and Cl- ions occupy another type of lattice site. Now
column3: we substitute a Na+ ion with a Ca2+ ion.

column1: Magnetism;8;G-XEC-2020-18;NUM;92;$Fe_(3)O_(4)$ (also represented as FeO.$Fe_(2)O_(3)$) is a FCC structured inverse spinel ($AB_2O_4) material where 1/8 of tetrahedral sites are occupied by half of B cations and 1/2 of the octahedral sites are occupied by remaining B and A cations. The magneteic moments of cations on octahedral sites are antiparallel with respect to those on tetrahedral sites. Atomic number of Fe is 26 and that of O is 8. The saturation magnetic moment of $Fe_(3)O_(4)$ per formula unit in terms of Bohr magnetons ($µ_B$) will be ? Ignore contribution from orbital magnetic moments.;"Let's break down the problem step by step:
1. The formula unit of Fe₃O₄ is FeO.Fe₂O₃
column2: which means we have one Fe²⁺ (A cation) and two Fe³⁺ (B cations) per formula unit.

column1: 2. The tetrahedral sites are occupied by half of the B cations
column2: which is one Fe³⁺ ion. The magnetic moment of Fe³⁺ is 5 µB (since it has 5 unpaired electrons).

column1: 3. The octahedral sites are occupied by the remaining B cation (one Fe³⁺) and the A cation (one Fe²⁺). The magnetic moment of Fe²⁺ is 4 µB (since it has 4 unpaired electrons). The magnetic moment of the second Fe³⁺ is also 5 µB.
4. Since the magnetic moments of cations on octahedral sites are antiparallel with respect to those on tetrahedral sites
column2: the net magnetic moment of the octahedral sites is 4 µB - 5 µB = -1 µB.

the resolution of backscattered electron (BSE) image is poorer compared to that of secondary electron (SE) image

column1: The resolution of an image in scanning electron microscopy is affected by the sampling volume of the electrons. The sampling volume refers to the volume of the sample from which the electrons are emitted or scattered.

Backscattered electrons have a larger sampling volume because they can travel deeper into the sample and be scattered back from a larger volume. This results in a poorer resolution compared to secondary electrons
column2: which have a smaller sampling volume and are emitted from a smaller region near the surface.
the correct answer is (B) sampling volume of BSE is larger.";;B;1;

column1: (A) Heating 10 mg of pure Cu from 323 K to 673 K: No phase transition occurs in this temperature range for pure Cu
column2: so no spike is expected.

column1: (B) Cooling pure water from 323 K to 278 K: Water will undergo a phase transition from liquid to solid (freezing) at 273 K
column2: which would result in a downward spike in the DSC thermogram.

column1: (C) Heating pure ice from 263 K to 284 K: Ice will undergo a phase transition from solid to liquid (melting) at 273 K
column2: which would result in an upward spike in the DSC thermogram.

column1: (D) Cooling a Pb-Sn alloy at the eutectic composition from 323 K to 273 K: At the eutectic composition
column2: the alloy will undergo a phase transition from liquid to solid at a specific temperature
column3: resulting in a downward spike in the DSC thermogram.

column1: * (B) Cooling pure water from 323 K to 278 K

* (D) Cooling a Pb-Sn alloy at the eutectic composition from 323 K to 273 K";;C;0;
